reference:
Because this is an experiment, where the race and gender attributes are
being randomly assigned to the resumes, we can conclude that any
statistically significant difference in callback rates is causally linked to
these attributes.
description:
Description
This experiment data comes from a study that sought to understand the
influence of race and gender on job application callback rates. The study
monitored job postings in Boston and Chicago for several months during 2001
and 2002 and used this to build up a set of test cases. Over this time
period, the researchers randomly generating resumes to go out to a job
posting, such as years of experience and education details, to create a
realistic-looking resume. They then randomly assigned a name to the resume
that would communicate the applicant's gender and race. The first names
chosen for the study were selected so that the names would predominantly be
recognized as belonging to black or white individuals. For example, Lakisha
was a name that their survey indicated would be interpreted as a black
woman, while Greg was a name that would generally be interpreted to be
associated with a white male.
title: Which resume attributes drive job callbacks?

parameters.volunteer:
Indicator for if volunteering was listed on the
resume.
parameters.worked_during_school:
Indicator for if the resume
listed working while in school.
parameters.years_experience:
Years of
experience listed on the resume.
parameters.job_req_communication:
Indicator for if communication skills
are required.
parameters.job_fed_contractor: Indicator for if the employer is a federal contractor.
parameters.race:
Inferred race associated with the first name on the
resume.
parameters.years_college:
Years of college
education listed on the resume.
parameters.has_email_address:
Indicator for if the resume lists an email
address.
parameters.honors:
Indicator for if the resume listed that the candidate has been awarded some
honors.
parameters.special_skills:
Indicator for
if any special skills were listed on the resume.
parameters.job_equal_opp_employer:
Indicator for if the employer is an
Equal Opportunity Employer.
parameters.job_city: City where the job was located.
parameters.job_req_organization: Indicator for if organization skills are required.
parameters.job_ownership:
The type of
company, e.g. a nonprofit or a private company.
parameters.military:
Indicator for if military experience was
listed on the resume.
parameters.received_callback:
Indicator for if there was a callback from
the job posting for the person listed on this resume.
parameters.resume_quality:
Each resume was generally
classified as either lower or higher quality.
parameters.gender:
Inferred gender associated with the first
name on the resume.
parameters.college_degree:
Indicator
for if the resume listed a college degree.
parameters.job_req_any:
Indicator for if any job requirements are
listed. If so, the other job_req_* fields give more detail.
parameters.job_ad_id: Unique ID associated with the advertisement.
parameters.firstname: The first name used on the resume.
parameters.job_req_computer:
Indicator
for if computer skills are required.
parameters.computer_skills:
Indicator for if computer skills were listed on the resume. These skills
were adapted for listings, though the skills were assigned independently of
other details on the resume.
parameters.job_req_education:
Indicator for if some
level of education is required.
parameters.employment_holes:
Indicator for if
there were holes in the person's employment history.

format:
A data frame with 4870 observations, representing 4870 resumes, over
30 different variables that describe the job details, the outcome
(received_callback), and attributes of the resume.
